We show that with only 100 real training samples, our framework achieves on average $87\%$ of the performance of the full real-world dataset. We publicly release our code and 140k+ synthetic document samples.

AI.tldr: DocDjinn is a framework that uses Vision-Language Models to generate synthetic documents from unlabeled seed samples, producing annotated, visually plausible documents for training document intelligence models while preserving privacy.
AI.motivation: Acquiring large annotated document datasets is labor-intensive, costly, and raises privacy concerns when using language models on real documents. Synthetic document generation offers a privacy-preserving alternative to data collection.
AI.method: Uses clustering-based seed selection with parametrized sampling from unlabeled samples, generates documents via Vision-Language Models with semantic-visual decoupling, and enriches them with diffusion-based handwriting and contextual visual elements.
AI.result: DocDjinn generates diverse, high-quality annotated synthetic documents that can approximate real data. With only 100 real training samples, it achieves 87% performance of full real-world datasets across 11 benchmarks for information extraction, QA, classification, and layout analysis.
AI.conclusion: DocDjinn demonstrates for the first time that Vision-Language Models can generate faithful annotated document datasets at scale from unlabeled seeds, effectively enriching or approximating real data for diverse document understanding tasks.

title: JSAM: Privacy Straggler-Resilient Joint Client Selection and Incentive Mechanism Design in Differentially Private Federated Learning
summary: Differentially private federated learning faces a fundamental tension: privacy protection mechanisms that safeguard client data simultaneously create quantifiable privacy costs that discourage participation, undermining the collaborative training process. Existing incentive mechanisms rely on unbiased client selection, forcing servers to compensate even the most privacy-sensitive clients ("privacy stragglers"), leading to systemic inefficiency and suboptimal resource allocation. We introduce JSAM (Joint client Selection and privacy compensAtion Mechanism), a Bayesian-optimal framework that simultaneously optimizes client selection probabilities and privacy compensation to maximize training effectiveness under budget constraints. Our approach transforms a complex 2N-dimensional optimization problem into an efficient three-dimensional formulation through novel theoretical characterization of optimal selection strategies. We prove that servers should preferentially select privacy-tolerant clients while excluding high-sensitivity participants, and uncover the counter-intuitive insight that clients with minimal privacy sensitivity may incur the highest cumulative costs due to frequent participation. Extensive evaluations on MNIST and CIFAR-10 demonstrate that JSAM achieves up to 15% improvement in test accuracy compared to existing unbiased selection mechanisms while maintaining cost efficiency across varying data heterogeneity levels.

AI.tldr: JSAM is a Bayesian-optimal framework for differentially private federated learning that jointly optimizes client selection probabilities and privacy compensation to maximize training effectiveness under budget constraints, achieving up to 15% better accuracy than unbiased selection methods.
AI.motivation: There's a fundamental tension in differentially private federated learning: privacy protection creates quantifiable privacy costs that discourage client participation, undermining collaborative training. Existing incentive mechanisms with unbiased client selection force servers to compensate even highly privacy-sensitive clients ("privacy stragglers"), leading to systemic inefficiency and suboptimal resource allocation.
AI.method: JSAM (Joint client Selection and privacy compensAtion Mechanism) uses Bayesian optimization to simultaneously optimize client selection probabilities and privacy compensation. The approach transforms a complex 2N-dimensional optimization problem into an efficient three-dimensional formulation through novel theoretical characterization of optimal selection strategies.
AI.result: Extensive evaluations on MNIST and CIFAR-10 show that JSAM achieves up to 15% improvement in test accuracy compared to existing unbiased selection mechanisms while maintaining cost efficiency across varying data heterogeneity levels. The analysis reveals servers should preferentially select privacy-tolerant clients while excluding high-sensitivity participants, and surprisingly shows that clients with minimal privacy sensitivity may incur the highest cumulative costs due to frequent participation.
AI.conclusion: JSAM provides an effective framework for optimizing differentially private federated learning by strategically selecting clients based on privacy tolerance and compensating them appropriately, significantly improving training effectiveness while respecting budget constraints.

title: The Error of Deep Operator Networks Is the Sum of Its Parts: Branch-Trunk and Mode Error Decompositions
summary:
Operator learning has the potential to strongly impact scientific computing by learning solution operators for differential equations, potentially accelerating multi-query tasks such as design optimization and uncertainty quantification by orders of magnitude. Despite proven universal approximation properties, deep operator networks (DeepONets) often exhibit limited accuracy and generalization in practice, which hinders their adoption. Understanding these limitations is therefore crucial for further advancing the approach.
  This work analyzes performance limitations of the classical DeepONet architecture. It is shown that the approximation error is dominated by the branch network when the internal dimension is sufficiently large, and that the learned trunk basis can often be replaced by classical basis functions without a significant impact on performance.
  To investigate this further, a modified DeepONet is constructed in which the trunk network is replaced by the left singular vectors of the training solution matrix. This modification yields several key insights. First, a spectral bias in the branch network is observed, with coefficients of dominant, low-frequency modes learned more effectively. Second, due to singular-value scaling of the branch coefficients, the overall branch error is dominated by modes with intermediate singular values rather than the smallest ones. Third, using a shared branch network for all mode coefficients, as in the standard architecture, improves generalization of small modes compared to a stacked architecture in which coefficients are computed separately. Finally, strong and detrimental coupling between modes in parameter space is identified.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes performance limitations of DeepONets, finding that approximation error is dominated by the branch network, and proposes modifications using singular value decomposition to investigate spectral bias and mode coupling issues.
AI.motivation: Despite the theoretical universal approximation capabilities of DeepONets, they often exhibit limited accuracy and poor generalization in practice, which hinders their adoption for scientific computing applications like design optimization and uncertainty quantification.
AI.method: The authors analyze the classical DeepONet architecture, showing the branch network dominates error. They propose a modified DeepONet where the trunk network is replaced by left singular vectors from training data, then investigate spectral bias, singular-value scaling effects, and compare shared branch networks vs. stacked architectures.
AI.result: Key findings include: 1) spectral bias in branch networks favoring low-frequency modes, 2) branch error dominated by modes with intermediate singular values due to scaling effects, 3) shared branch networks generalize better than stacked architectures, and 4) strong detrimental coupling exists between modes in parameter space.
AI.conclusion: DeepONet limitations stem from branch network issues and mode coupling. The trunk network's learned basis can often be replaced by classical basis functions without significant performance loss, suggesting architectural improvements should focus on branch network design and handling mode interactions.

title: Learning in the Null Space: Small Singular Values for Continual Learning
comment: 17 pages, accepted as Oral presentation at the Third Conference on Parsimony and Learning (CPAL 2026)
summary: Alleviating catastrophic forgetting while enabling further learning is a primary challenge in continual learning (CL). Orthogonal-based training methods have gained attention for their efficiency and strong theoretical properties, and many existing approaches enforce orthogonality through gradient projection. In this paper, we revisit orthogonality and exploit the fact that small singular values correspond to directions that are nearly orthogonal to the input space of previous tasks. Building on this principle, we introduce NESS (Null-space Estimated from Small Singular values), a CL method that applies orthogonality directly in the weight space rather than through gradient manipulation. Specifically, NESS constructs an approximate null space using the smallest singular values of each layer's input representation and parameterizes task-specific updates via a compact low-rank adaptation (LoRA-style) formulation constrained to this subspace. The subspace basis is fixed to preserve the null-space constraint, and only a single trainable matrix is learned for each task. This design ensures that the resulting updates remain approximately in the null space of previous inputs while enabling adaptation to new tasks. Our theoretical analysis and experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate competitive performance, low forgetting, and stable accuracy across tasks, highlighting the role of small singular values in continual learning. The code is available at https://github.com/pacman-ctm/NESS.

AI.tldr: NESS is a continual learning method that uses small singular values to identify near-null spaces, allowing task-specific updates that don't interfere with previous learning through a LoRA-style parameterization.
AI.motivation: To address catastrophic forgetting in continual learning by leveraging the observation that small singular values correspond to directions nearly orthogonal to previous task inputs, allowing for better isolation of new task updates.
AI.method: NESS constructs an approximate null space using the smallest singular values of each layer's input representation, then parameterizes task-specific updates via a compact low-rank adaptation (LoRA-style) formulation constrained to this subspace with fixed basis and single trainable matrix per task.
AI.result: Experiments on three benchmark datasets show competitive performance, low forgetting, and stable accuracy across tasks, demonstrating the effectiveness of small singular values in continual learning.
AI.conclusion: Small singular values play a crucial role in continual learning by identifying near-null spaces that allow task-specific updates while preserving previous knowledge, offering an effective alternative to gradient projection methods.

title: Learning Unknown Interdependencies for Decentralized Root Cause Analysis in Nonlinear Dynamical Systems
summary: Root cause analysis (RCA) in networked industrial systems, such as supply chains and power networks, is notoriously difficult due to unknown and dynamically evolving interdependencies among geographically distributed clients. These clients represent heterogeneous physical processes and industrial assets equipped with sensors that generate large volumes of nonlinear, high-dimensional, and heterogeneous IoT data. Classical RCA methods require partial or full knowledge of the system's dependency graph, which is rarely available in these complex networks. While federated learning (FL) offers a natural framework for decentralized settings, most existing FL methods assume homogeneous feature spaces and retrainable client models. These assumptions are not compatible with our problem setting. Different clients have different data features and often run fixed, proprietary models that cannot be modified. This paper presents a federated cross-client interdependency learning methodology for feature-partitioned, nonlinear time-series data, without requiring access to raw sensor streams or modifying proprietary client models. Each proprietary local client model is augmented with a Machine Learning (ML) model that encodes cross-client interdependencies. These ML models are coordinated via a global server that enforces representation consistency while preserving privacy through calibrated differential privacy noise. RCA is performed using model residuals and anomaly flags. We establish theoretical convergence guarantees and validate our approach on extensive simulations and a real-world industrial cybersecurity dataset.

AI.tldr: Federated RCA method for networked industrial systems that learns cross-client interdependencies without accessing raw data or modifying proprietary client models, using ML augmentations and differential privacy.
AI.motivation: RCA in complex networked industrial systems is difficult due to unknown/dynamic interdependencies among geographically distributed clients, heterogeneous feature spaces, fixed proprietary models, and lack of system dependency graph knowledge.
AI.method: Augments each proprietary client model with ML models to encode cross-client interdependencies, coordinated via global server with calibrated differential privacy noise. RCA uses model residuals and anomaly flags while preserving privacy.
AI.result: Method provides theoretical convergence guarantees and is validated on extensive simulations and real-world industrial cybersecurity dataset, showing effectiveness for RCA in networked industrial systems.
AI.conclusion: Proposes a practical federated RCA framework that addresses real-world constraints of networked industrial systems including feature heterogeneity, proprietary models, and privacy preservation.

title: Bayesian Generative Adversarial Networks via Gaussian Approximation for Tabular Data Synthesis
comment: 28 pages, 5 Figures, Accepted in Transactions on Data Privacy
summary: Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) have been used in many studies to synthesise mixed tabular data. Conditional tabular GAN (CTGAN) have been the most popular variant but struggle to effectively navigate the risk-utility trade-off. Bayesian GAN have received less attention for tabular data, but have been explored with unstructured data such as images and text. The most used technique employed in Bayesian GAN is Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), but it is computationally intensive, particularly in terms of weight storage. In this paper, we introduce Gaussian Approximation of CTGAN (GACTGAN), an integration of the Bayesian posterior approximation technique using Stochastic Weight Averaging-Gaussian (SWAG) within the CTGAN generator to synthesise tabular data, reducing computational overhead after the training phase. We demonstrate that GACTGAN yields better synthetic data compared to CTGAN, achieving better preservation of tabular structure and inferential statistics with less privacy risk. These results highlight GACTGAN as a simpler, effective implementation of Bayesian tabular synthesis.

AI.tldr: GACTGAN integrates Bayesian posterior approximation using SWAG into CTGAN for tabular data synthesis, achieving better utility-privacy trade-off than CTGAN with lower computational overhead.
AI.motivation: CTGAN struggles with risk-utility trade-off in tabular data synthesis, while Bayesian GANs using MCMC are computationally intensive. There's a need for simpler Bayesian approaches for tabular data.
AI.method: Introduces GACTGAN which integrates Stochastic Weight Averaging-Gaussian (SWAG) technique for Bayesian posterior approximation within the CTGAN generator to synthesize tabular data, reducing computational overhead.
AI.result: GACTGAN yields better synthetic data than CTGAN, achieving better preservation of tabular structure and inferential statistics with less privacy risk, while being computationally more efficient.
AI.conclusion: GACTGAN represents a simpler, effective implementation of Bayesian tabular synthesis that improves on CTGAN's limitations while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: Estimation and Optimization of Ship Fuel Consumption in Maritime: Review, Challenges and Future Directions
comment: 23 pages, 4 figures. Published in Journal of Marine Science and Technology (2026)
summary: To reduce carbon emissions and minimize shipping costs, improving the fuel efficiency of ships is crucial. Various measures are taken to reduce the total fuel consumption of ships, including optimizing vessel parameters and selecting routes with the lowest fuel consumption. Different estimation methods are proposed for predicting fuel consumption, while various optimization methods are proposed to minimize fuel oil consumption. This paper provides a comprehensive review of methods for estimating and optimizing fuel oil consumption in maritime transport. Our novel contributions include categorizing fuel oil consumption \& estimation methods into physics-based, machine-learning, and hybrid models, exploring their strengths and limitations. Furthermore, we highlight the importance of data fusion techniques, which combine AIS, onboard sensors, and meteorological data to enhance accuracy. We make the first attempt to discuss the emerging role of Explainable AI in enhancing model transparency for decision-making. Uniquely, key challenges, including data quality, availability, and the need for real-time optimization, are identified, and future research directions are proposed to address these gaps, with a focus on hybrid models, real-time optimization, and the standardization of datasets.

AI.tldr: Comprehensive review of fuel oil consumption estimation and optimization methods in maritime transport, covering physics-based, machine learning, and hybrid models, with emphasis on data fusion and Explainable AI.
AI.motivation: To reduce carbon emissions and shipping costs by improving fuel efficiency through better estimation and optimization methods.
AI.method: Literature review categorizing fuel consumption estimation methods into physics-based, machine learning, and hybrid models; exploring data fusion techniques combining AIS, onboard sensors, and meteorological data; discussing Explainable AI for transparency.
AI.result: Systematic categorization of existing methods, identification of strengths/limitations of different approaches, highlighting of data fusion importance, and first discussion of Explainable AI role in maritime fuel optimization.
AI.conclusion: Identifies key challenges (data quality, availability, real-time optimization needs) and proposes future research directions focusing on hybrid models, real-time optimization, and dataset standardization.

title: Robustness in sparse artificial neural networks trained with adaptive topology
summary: We investigate the robustness of sparse artificial neural networks trained with adaptive topology. We focus on a simple yet effective architecture consisting of three sparse layers with 99% sparsity followed by a dense layer, applied to image classification tasks such as MNIST and Fashion MNIST. By updating the topology of the sparse layers between each epoch, we achieve competitive accuracy despite the significantly reduced number of weights. Our primary contribution is a detailed analysis of the robustness of these networks, exploring their performance under various perturbations including random link removal, adversarial attack, and link weight shuffling. Through extensive experiments, we demonstrate that adaptive topology not only enhances efficiency but also maintains robustness. This work highlights the potential of adaptive sparse networks as a promising direction for developing efficient and reliable deep learning models.

AI.tldr: Adaptive sparse neural networks maintain robustness while achieving efficiency through topology updates.
AI.motivation: To investigate the robustness of sparse artificial neural networks with adaptive topology in image classification tasks, aiming to reduce computational costs while maintaining performance.
AI.method: Use a simple architecture with three sparse layers (99% sparsity) followed by a dense layer. Update topology between epochs and test robustness against perturbations like random link removal, adversarial attacks, and weight shuffling.
AI.result: Achieve competitive accuracy on MNIST and Fashion MNIST despite reduced weights. Demonstrate that adaptive topology enhances efficiency while maintaining robustness under various perturbations.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive sparse networks show promise for developing efficient and reliable deep learning models through their combination of high sparsity, dynamic topology updates, and maintained robustness.

title: Compact Circulant Layers with Spectral Priors
summary: Critical applications in areas such as medicine, robotics and autonomous systems require compact (i.e., memory efficient), uncertainty-aware neural networks suitable for edge and other resource-constrained deployments. We study compact spectral circulant and block-circulant-with-circulant-blocks (BCCB) layers: FFT-diagonalizable circular convolutions whose weights live directly in the real FFT (RFFT) half (1D) or half-plane (2D). Parameterizing filters in the frequency domain lets us impose simple spectral structure, perform structured variational inference in a low-dimensional weight space, and calculate exact layer spectral norms, enabling inexpensive global Lipschitz bounds and margin-based robustness diagnostics. By placing independent complex Gaussians on the Hermitian support we obtain a discrete instance of the spectral representation of stationary kernels, inducing an exact stationary Gaussian-process prior over filters on the discrete circle/torus. We exploit this to define a practical spectral prior and a Hermitian-aware low-rank-plus-diagonal variational posterior in real coordinates. Empirically, spectral circulant/BCCB layers are effective compact building blocks in both (variational) Bayesian and point estimate regimes: compact Bayesian neural networks on MNIST->Fashion-MNIST, variational heads on frozen CIFAR-10 features, and deterministic ViT projections on CIFAR-10/Tiny ImageNet; spectral layers match strong baselines while using substantially fewer parameters and with tighter Lipschitz certificates.

AI.tldr: Spectral circulant and BCCB layers as compact, uncertainty-aware neural network building blocks with exact spectral structure, Lipschitz bounds, and Gaussian process priors.
AI.motivation: Need for compact, memory-efficient neural networks with uncertainty quantification for resource-constrained deployments in critical applications like medicine and robotics.
AI.method: Use spectral circulant and block-circulant-with-circulant-blocks (BCCB) layers parameterized in frequency domain via FFT diagonalization, with spectral structure imposition, variational inference in low-dimensional weight space, and Gaussian process priors via independent complex Gaussians.
AI.result: Spectral layers match strong baselines on MNIST->Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR-10 features, and CIFAR-10/Tiny ImageNet with deterministic ViT projections, while using substantially fewer parameters and providing tighter Lipschitz certificates.
AI.conclusion: Spectral circulant/BCCB layers are effective compact building blocks that enable memory efficiency, uncertainty quantification, and Lipschitz certification for resource-constrained applications.

title: Neural solver for Wasserstein Geodesics and optimal transport dynamics
summary: In recent years, the machine learning community has increasingly embraced the optimal transport (OT) framework for modeling distributional relationships. In this work, we introduce a sample-based neural solver for computing the Wasserstein geodesic between a source and target distribution, along with the associated velocity field. Building on the dynamical formulation of the optimal transport (OT) problem, we recast the constrained optimization as a minimax problem, using deep neural networks to approximate the relevant functions. This approach not only provides the Wasserstein geodesic but also recovers the OT map, enabling direct sampling from the target distribution. By estimating the OT map, we obtain velocity estimates along particle trajectories, which in turn allow us to learn the full velocity field. The framework is flexible and readily extends to general cost functions, including the commonly used quadratic cost. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method through experiments on both synthetic and real datasets.

AI.tldr: A neural network-based approach for computing Wasserstein geodesics and velocity fields between distributions, enabling direct sampling from target distributions through optimal transport mapping.
AI.motivation: The machine learning community increasingly uses optimal transport framework for modeling distributional relationships, but needs efficient computational methods for Wasserstein geodesics and velocity fields that can handle complex distributions and enable direct sampling.
AI.method: Uses deep neural networks to approximate relevant functions in a minimax formulation of optimal transport's dynamical formulation. The approach computes Wasserstein geodesics and recovers OT maps for direct sampling, then uses these maps to estimate velocity along particle trajectories and learn the full velocity field.
AI.result: The method effectively computes Wasserstein geodesics and velocity fields, works with various cost functions including quadratic cost, and demonstrates performance on both synthetic and real datasets.
AI.conclusion: The neural solver provides a flexible, sample-based framework for computing Wasserstein geodesics and velocity fields that extends to general cost functions and enables practical applications in distribution modeling and sampling.
